Award.AwardTitle: Doping Dependent Transition from Paramagnetism to Ferromagnetism in Semiconductors
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical abstract

In order to accelerate the technological revolution that has placed high speed computation and information storage at our fingertips almost anywhere on Earth, new ideas are essential. One pathway for progress in semiconductor device design, known as spintronics, seeks to make use of the magnetic degrees of freedom to the same extent that charge degrees of freedom are used in present day silicon technologies. As scientists have sought to control or manipulate the electron spin, the intrinsic magnetic property of electrons, they have recognized the utility of materials that are both magnetic and semiconducting. However, of the small number of such systems presently known, none completely meet requirements such as compatibility with silicon, room temperature magnetism, and the possibility of coupling to electrical and optical signals that are necessary for spintronics technologies. As is true of many nascent technologies, fundamental explorations of material and physical properties can lead to breakthroughs. This project investigates a range of magnetic and semiconducting materials to explore the mechanisms for magnetism which includes the interaction of electronic and magnetic degrees of freedom and to document the ramifications of these interactions on the physical properties of these systems. Students on many levels, as well as high school teachers, will be exploring magnetic, electric, optical, and thermodynamic properties of these magnetic semiconductors in crystalline, thin film, and nanowire form.


Technical abstract

Although magnetic semiconductors have received enormous attention because of their potential use in spintronics devices, from a fundamental viewpoint they remain poorly explored. In particular, it has been very difficult to separate the often overwhelming defect related issues from the more interesting essential behaviors. This project will investigate a set of magnetic and semiconducting silicides and sulfides where careful characterization has demonstrated that secondary phases and defect related issues are not relevant. This control over materials properties allows access to a unique regime, that near the transition(s) from paramagnetic insulator to magnetic metal in a semiconductor by way of chemical substitution in crystals, thin films, and nanowires. Students on many levels, as well as high school teachers will be exploring these materials searching for novel transport, magnetic, thermodynamic, and optical properties that may, perhaps, be exploited in future technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: This project resulted in several discoveries in the electronic and magnetic properties of materials. The majority of these resulted from explorations into the properties of magnetic semiconductors where the combination of disorder, low carrier density, and strong electrical carrier interactions lead to rich novel behavior. We investigated the magnetic and electrical transport properties of several iron containing semiconductors, silicides and sulfides, to explore onset of ferromagnetism with chemical substitution. This is an important and interesting area since it is relatively unexplored and it may prove important for progress in identifying magnetic semiconductors that are useful to the nascent technology known as spintronics. We found that relatively large, yet rare, regions in materials on the verge of magnetic orderings can dominate their behaviors in ways not previously appreciated. These rare regions are continuously fluctuating in time and space leading to novel behaviors. In addition, we discovered that interesting behavior can be found when doping transition metal impurities into these semiconductors leads to large uncompensated moments. Here, we discovered evidence that the underscreening that results leads to behavior that cannot be understood within the standard model of metals that has been enormously successful over nearly a century of exploration of condensed matter systems.

We have also explored materials designed to lie close to quantum criticality – where a phase transition has been driven to near zero temperature . This has led to equally as interesting discoveries in their magnetic and electrical response. We have explored the changes to the electronic structure and to the effective mass of the electrical carriers as they are driven through this interesting region. These experiments not only allowed us to investigate materials where quantum fluctuations dominate their behavior, but also to compare with predictions of electronic and magnetic properties of materials. Some of these experiments were carried out at the NSF’s National High Magnetic Field Laboratory where fields of up to 65 T were accessed.

Other investigations were carried out to explore the properties of layer materials where the coupling between the layers can be tuned with moderate hydrodynamic pressure. Here we found that a superconducting transition can be tuned through a 2- to 3-dimensional behavior resulting in a dramatic change in its properties. This is the same compound, LaSb2, where a very large positive, linear-in-magnetic field, magnetoresistance had been identified, but not fully understood.

Broader Impact: Because this project involved the investigations of the properties of magnetic semiconductors which are thought to be important for the future technology of spintronics and because this project supported the work of 2 graduate students, seven undergraduate students, and two teachers participating in the Teach for America program, we believe that this project may have a much broader impact than the intellectual accomplishments outlined above. Because of the student training and inclusion of teachers in the research program, this project has impacted the development of young men and women in important STEM fields at several stages of their development. The inclusion of the teachers allowed our research to be presented to underserved, mostly minority, high school students and to host these students through a tour of our facilities. The goal was to encourage their interest and development in physical science.
